p: A major problem with review of the historical literature for evidence of animal influenza is that the further one goes back in time, the more difficult it becomes provisionally to identify influenza. Before the 16th century, epidemics of all kinds were usually recorded by laymen without medical vocabularies, and without appreciation of etiology, pathogenesis, natural history, distinctive/pathognomonic signs, or any of the modern ways in which we now diagnose, identify, and classify specific diseases. Even such distinct diseases as measles and smallpox were long confused with each other.
